For several months now I've been reviewing the literature of the "New Atheism", a literature of scientific triumphalism propelled and elevated to bestseller status by the disaster of 9/11.  Now that Osama bin Laden has been killed, it seems like an appropriate moment to think about whether the New Atheism measures up to the event which created it, or made it "new".  Of course there was atheism before 9/11, but in the modern sense of the word, "atheism" is barely 200 years old, and arguably less.  Before that, "atheism" was an epithet hurled at people who had different religious ideas, not people who rejected religion entirely.  Before revolutionary liberal democracy imposed a firm separation of Church and State, you could not be an "atheist" in the modern sense.  It would be treason.  A skeptic could only promote religious change.  

Richard Dawkins sums this up with the quip: "We are all atheists about most of the gods that humanity has ever believed in. Some of us just go one god further."  Is 9/11 an object lesson, and valid reason to go "one god further"?

<lj-cut text="Read More...">

None of what the New Atheists say seems "new" to me.  It all seems like somehting I've heard before, from within the Western religious tradition.  Standing outside of religion, or clothing your arguments in the mantle of "Science" or "Reason" doesn't seem to add anything.

All three of the Abrahamic religions (Judaism, Christianity and Islam) were once "new" doctrines.  All three have strong elements of what I will call religious "nihilism": efforts to devalue and demonize competing religious culture. It is no defense to "nihilism" to assert that the world has meaning and value through God.  Monotheism makes that impossible.  The abstract, logically impossible attributes of the Abrahamic God (omniscience, omnipotence) defy all attempts to derive meaning from God's existence, at least in the manner that polytheistic religions worked (by imputing human motivations to the gods).  God's motives were asserted to be inscrutable, imagining the God in "graven images" was prohibited, trying to contact the dead and gain the wisdom of the ancestors was demonized as sorcery or necromancy... the list goes on and on.     

What was the impetus for all this hostility to religion, in the guise of religion itself?  Imperialism. The kingdom of Judea was caught in a power vacuum caused by the fall of the Assyrian Empire, the rise of the Babylonians and their rivalry with the empire of Egypt to the south.  Some Jews backed the Egyptians.  This precipitated an invasion by Babylon in which the walls and Temple in Jerusalem were destroyed.  The royal family and many others were taken hostage and transported to Mesopotamia (hence the term "Babylonian Captivity"). This became part of a wider Jewish diaspora which included Jews relocated to other centers such as Egypt.  It was during this period (600 BC - 500 BC) that scholars believe the Bible took its final written form.  The Temple was eventually rebuilt, but its religious meaning was forever changed.  It was no longer viable to worship the Lord as a tribal god, able (or willing) to promote the political ends of the Jewish kingdom.  The Jewish god was re-valued as Lord (whose name was never spoken) whose primary characteristic was anger at the people for their sins, as a way of explaining their subjugated political status and the many calamities which they suffered as a nation.

These Jews who write the Bible could and did borrow good ideas from the Babylonians: the Ten Commandments and other parts of the Law clearly come form the Code of Hammurabi, and employ the idea of  punishments fixed in advance for particular offenses.   They drew the line at magic, however.  Why?  For a post-Exilic Jew, divination and sorcery were the religion of their oppressors. The Jews were overrun and dispersed by an advanced civilization.  Mesopotamians had been brewing beer for thousands of years.  Archeologists can argue about cause and effect here: was agricultural surplus the impetus for beer, or was a desire to make more beer the driving force behind, but either way, alcohol and civilization go together.  Early Babylonian astronomy is the source of the Zodiac and the rudiments of astrology.  Around the time they conquered Palestine, the Babylonians may have been making batteries: acid-filled jars with copper and iron parts connected with lead-tin solder, possibly for electroplating gold on silver, possibly to create "special effects" for religious idols. If we were invaded tomorrow by technologically advanced space aliens, it might not be as shocking to us.

By reading the Bible only, it's difficult to say whether the Jews, by adopting monotheism coupled with a vigorous religious nihilism with respect to all the religious culture around them, were acting as oppressors or the oppressed.  The Jews took pride in their acts of oppression, shameful as it seems to modern sensibilities.  The texts of the Old Testament detail numerous atrocities committed against the native Canaanites for religious reasons.  In light of non-biblical archeological and historic evidence, however, I'm not willing to take any of that at face value.  Adopting a strict new religion is hardly necessary for demonizing your enemies or creating excuses for hegemonic violence.  It may be necessary, on the other hand, to ensure cultural survival for the victims of such violence.  We know that Judea was overrun by one empire after another: Egypt, Assyria, Babylon, Macedon, Rome.  While I have no doubt that the Hebrew kingdoms committed all the atrocities they boast of (and more) I believe the reconfiguration of God as a monotheistic abstraction is a response to overwhelming cultural, military and economic force from the outside. 

The God of Moses, the power which delivered and "saved" the people from bondage in "Egypt", is the  God which turned out to have staying power in the imagination of humankind, long after all tribal gods invoked in battle have been forgotten.  We have heard echoes of the Prophetic theme of justice and righteous in my lifetime, as when Martin Luther King, Jr. quoted Amos 5:24 in his "I Have a Dream Speech" ("No, no, we are not satisfied, and we will not be satisfied until justice rolls down like waters and righteousness like a mighty stream.")  Collective salvation, the liberation of nations and peoples, seems to go hand-in-hand with condemnation of superstition and mindless ritual.  Jews under the Babylonians, Christians under the Romans, Germans burdened with rapacious taxes under the Roman Church during the Reformation: all demanded a simpler form of religion with social justice at the forefront. All lashed out with iconoclasm and nihilism at the complex forms of art and culture and politics which were encrusted upon older, established (and in their view, "corrupted") religion.  Tillich calls this nihilism "the Protestant Principle" (taking a historical view of repeating cycles of theological movements, of which the Reformation is probably the most dramatic) though one could take a psychological view and call it simply "humility" (less annoying to Catholics, that way).  I prefer to call it "nihilism" to remind myself that, when it manifests itself in history as a strong political movement, it's often accompanied by wars or pogroms or various other forms of psychotic violence. 

The New Atheists can object that fundamentalists represent "true" or "natural" religion, and that more sophisticated views which incorporate doubt, skepticism and humility are merely a whitewash promulgated by elite, contemporary intellectuals to defend Religion against the implacable and inevitable March of Science.  This is the position Dan Dennett takes in "Breaking the Spell", and it is utter and total hogwash.  Dennett mistakes fundamentalism for religion (by defining religion as belief in a supernatural agent who must be appeased).  This isn't religion, this is legalism or fundamentalism: an extreme form of religious orthodoxy used to mask objections to social change.  With respect to the Abrahamic religious traditions which have religious skepticism built into them, fundamentalism is a perversion, reversal, and repudiation.  Fundamentalists make God their mouthpiece for the preservation of peculiar, obsolete cultural habits, rather than the judge of those habits.  Today's fundamentalists, be they "Christians" who shoot abortion doctors, or "Muslims" who bomb buildings, all seem pretty damn sure that their obsolete cultural concerns (all somehow related to the subjugation of women) constitute the Law of God.  They lack humility and doubt, which I think disqualifies them as true Christians or true Muslims.  On the other hand, I'm perfectly willing to admit that what I call "true" Christianity may be want I want it to be, rather than what it is.  I'm perfectly willing to jettison "fact" in favor of an aspirational goal of a better religion.  

You can object that the skepticism or nihilism which is internal to the Abrahamic traditions is not an all-encompassing religious nihilism, just a selected one.  You can say that the various writers of the Bible, and all the theologians since, are all united in condemning the religions of others, but not their own.  You can call that lack of self-reflection "hypocrisy" or intellectual dishonesty if you like, or like Dennett, you can construct an elaborate hypothesis that theological doubt is just a self-protection mechanism intended to put religion beyond rational discussion (an "adaptation" which insures survival of the viral religious "meme" through replication over time).  In context, though, it seems many peoples at many times have used militant monotheism as a sword and shield against the oppression of a dominant culture.  One could say the same about Islamic extremists today.  The history of Islam has included a wide variety of sects, from the skeptical-rational to the mystical-absurd and everything in between.  Rather than embrace this diversity, the Wahabist Muslim extremists seem to take a very selective slice of their culture which emphasizes their differences from global Western society.  The result is fanatic violence, but is this a case of "too much" religion, or not enough?

There seems to be a major blind spot in Anglo-American empirical skepticism.  Science did not give us liberal democracy.  Our constitutions and legal institutions were not developed in manner of empirical, natural science: by observation, experimentation and peer review.  "Experience" (in the sense of history) may have led to the recognition of these "rights", and "experience" is our guide in implementing them in a legal tradition.  We lawyers argue from books and precedents, but we do not assert hypotheses and then test them under controlled conditions.  Science has become an independent source of "evidence", in fact, the most important and only truly reliable source of evidence in the modern courtroom.   Evidence, however, determines "facts" not "law": it shapes a case and suggests a decision, but it doesn't establish the rules which will be invoked to justify the decision.  For example, in a murder case, forensic evidence might prove that the accused committed the crime.  But the definition of the crime, what constitutes "murder", is decided by law.   Laws change.  Even religious laws: Paul said the letter kills but the spirit gives life, and helped define Christianity by relieving Christians of many of the burdens of Jewish law.  Fundamentalists rationalize these changes away with bizarre and elaborate theories like "dispensationalism" and the New Atheists argue as if these changes have never happened.  Ultimately I find this just as tiresome and despicable as fundamentalism.  

Let me take another legal example which troubles me about the New Atheism: their universal revulsion for the religious indoctrination of children.  Just as 9/11 helped make the case that religious extremism is dangerous, the worldwide pedophile priest scandal in the Catholic Church helps support a case that religious indoctrination is abuse.  I can get behind legal action in specific cases of abuse.  If there's some tangible harm, like sexual abuse or withholding medical care, I don't think you'll find a lawyer in any civilized place in the world who would not recognize a "cause of action" in theory (though of course we reserve judgment until allegations are proven).  The New Atheists, however, ask more of me.  They want me to consider brain-washing children into superstitious ignorance as a civil rights violation in itself.  Religious indoctrination certainly has its cruel aspects, causes massive suffering and fuels an anger which seems to be taking on the character of a political movement.  Indeed, one might say that the rising tide of resentment is what the New Atheists are surfing on, which sells so many books.  The suggestion that society should intervene and protect children from religious indoctrination, however, runs smack into the "free exercise" clause of the First Amendment (or similar statements in international law, such as the Universal Declaration of Human Rights).  I am completely at a loss when it comes to concrete ways to address this.  Everything I've said above depends not only on adult rationality but a high level of education.  I don't impose my religious views on my kids, I don't even go to church anymore.  We're not talking about me personally, or what I should do, or what you should do.  We're talking about invading other people's privacy and violating their right to religious liberty.  I must admit that when it comes to people who teach their children that dinosaurs walked with Jesus, or that God hates fags, the idea of intervention sounds attractive.

When Facebook changed the "status" interface, I used that opportunity to do a couple of things.  First I confirmed my marriage, something Katy found delightful.  She thought it was like having one of those ceremonies where you re-affirm your vows, only in cyberspace.  

Then I changed my "Religion" from "Progressive Christian" to "Christian Atheist".  I did this primarily to scare off so-called "Christians", i.e. Christofascists.  Much to my surprise this triggered a phone call from Mom (a retired Lutheran pastor) wondering if this was desperate cry for help in the midst of some personal crisis.  I had to reassure her there was no personal crisis, that the timing of the thing had to do with a software update and not anything going on with me, though there is a greater political crisis going on.  

<lj-cut text="Read More...">

Talking with my mom, I may have mentioned the 2009 Churchwide Assembly in our denomination, the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America, wherein a surprisingly large number of representatives objected to ordaining homosexuals in committed relationships, and now are dragging their members out to yet another break-away Lutheran synod, the North American Lutheran Church.  

I did not mention that I prefer to call the NALC the "Nazi American Lutheran Church", in remembrance of all the Lutherans who called themselves "German Christians" and supported the Nazis with rabid anti-semitism.   I know my mother stands among the majority of Lutherans who take seriously Jesus' suggestion that we remove the plank from our own eyes before reaching for the speck in our neighbor's eye, so I didn't beat her up with this.  I didn't ask her in an argumentative way why ordination is still considered a "big deal" in a denomination which purportedly endorses the "priesthood of all believers".  I know my mother regards her own ordination as a great blessing, and a unique opportunity to provide education, consolation and therapy (she's a former psychiatric nurse) to whole groups of people, which has fulfilled and completed and perfected her life.  I'm not going to stomp on all that by arguing that there is something seriously wrong with our Church and its seminaries if it still ordains homophobic Nazis.  My mother quite capable of admitting (in private) that the Church is full of awful, evil trouble-makers.  It's a topic which makes us both feel very sad, though sometimes it's fun to gossip about the bad people.

And this conversation took place before I read the news that a legislator in South Dakota proposed a law (fortunately tabled) allowing murderers to set up a "justifiable homicide" defense for killing doctors who provide abortions.  In light of this constant drumbeat of virulent evil in the name of Jesus, however, I think I'll leave my Facebook status just the way it is.

Jesus took delight in paradox and it seems this above all things was the part of my Christian upbringing that left the most lasting impression on me.  In reality, "Christian Atheist" isn't a paradox at all, when viewed in light of the critique of "theism" offered by Christians like John Selby Spong.  But for people who don't read such books I suppose it's enough of a contradiction to make their heads explode (which I would consider a desirable result).  I understand that most people cannot separate "theism" from traditional religious belief, but it was not at all hard for me, as a life-long skeptic about all things "supernatural".  Naive faith in miracles, virgin births, immortality of the soul and the like has always struck me as fiction rather than fact.  From childhood it seemed obvious to me that not only were these things unproven and unprovable, but also incoherent.   Entirely aside from truth or falsity, I always wanted to know "what does that even mean?"

Take the afterlife, for example.  I started reading the New Testament, on my own and without adult guidance, when I was twelve.  I soon ran across an argument between Jesus and the Sadducees about the Resurrection.  (Mark 12:18 et seq.).  "Doctors of the law" pose a question to Jesus about a woman whose husband dies, and then according to tradition, she marries her late husband's brother.  This happens seven times until she has been married to seven brothers.  They then ask Jesus: to whom is she married?  Jesus replies that after the Resurrection we have "spiritual" bodies and that marriage becomes irrelevant.  So my twelve year old self wanted to know, what the heck is a "spiritual" body?  When we affirm "resurrection of the body" (as we did in Church whenever we recited the Creeds) what did that mean?   As I got older and my education progressed, I encountered many possible answers to that question: soul, spirit, atman.  I encountered Dante's vision of Paradise as well as Mark Twain's reply that most people have trouble enduring a few hours of hymn-singing let alone all eternity.  I encountered people seriously wondering whether they favorite pet had a soul: will Fluffy be with me in Heaven?  You say "yes" and secretly roll your eyes, like you would for a kid who insists on the truth about Santa Claus.  

The turning point in my education was discovering Kierkegaard in college and learning that the contradictions and paradoxes in Christian dogma are not a "flaw" in the "argument" but rather a very deliberate design feature and intentional manner of communication.  They are like Zen koans: designed to make you think "outside the box" (as we so blithely put it these days).  They are like the questions of Socrates, intended to create a state of "aporia" by demolishing the safety of false opinions.  They are supposed to be a "scandal" and "offense": doesn't the Bible say as much?  It has always been explicitly and honestly presented as absurd, at least by people who know what they are talking about, beginning with Jesus and Paul. These are stories we tell to make this life better.  

Now I find the world divides itself into two camps: the few people who understand this and the vast majority who do not.  For decades now, I have proceeded under the assumption that there is an esoteric Christianity for those who understand, and an exoteric Christianity for people who can't be bothered to think about it.  The "exoteric" camp includes not only dim-witted "believers" in the "literal truth" but also an ever-increasing number of militant atheists, people who take the Word literally and superficially and say: "that's ridiculous!" without realizing or acknowledging that it's supposed to be ridiculous.  I can hardly fault them for not taking the next required step (the "leap of faith" as it were).  It's just not easy, it can cause great personal suffering, and worst of all, many people find themselves trapped midway through the process.  It's like people who take LSD after being promised that it will change the way they look at the world.  For some people that's just what happens, for others it's a "bad trip", full of terror and paranoia and never resolving itself upon the clear plateau where the meaning and importance of everything in the sensory world is transformed.  If you don't like the illegal drug analogy then consider the autobiographical statements of saints and teachers.  Luther was constantly plagued with despair about his own sinfulness, to the point of psychosis, and had to "unceasingly" reaffirm his sense, understanding and feeling of the grace of God and the truth of the Gospel.  

If that's all there was to it, I might go around the world confidently preaching Christ (and him crucified) with the hope that some few might understand what I really mean.  Preaching to the choir, as it were.  But unfortunately that's not all there is to it.  There is also the political angle to consider. To consider yourself "in the know" here, you also have to understand and account for the (very bad) consequences of exoteric Christianity, and the historical fact that the religion was hijacked as the State Religion of the Roman Empire around the year 300 C.E., that a multitude of alternative "Christianities" were suppressed by patriarchal councils shortly thereafter.  Ever since the forces of Political Christianity have adapted and modified the religion to support all kinds of truly awful evil institutions, such as slavery, religious war, feudalism, monarchism and fascism.  This abuse of religion for reactionary political agendas continues today with the pro-Life movement, Catholic fascism, and with racism, sexism and homophobia in the Protestants sects (who really ought to know better but amazingly and obviously do not).  Against this sort of thing one has to be unpleasant and unfriendly, to the point of risking misinterpretation.  I'm really a Skeptic, not a throw-the-baby-Jesus-out-with-the-bathwater Atheist.  Given a choice between the dunderhead atheists and virulently evil religious fascists, however, I'm going to side with the atheists every time, thank-you-very-much, because they at least understand liberal democracy.  They don't burn heretics at the stake, or shoot abortion doctors, or blow up office buildings.  As between people who would kill me and people who would bore me with their clumsy critiques, I'll go with being bored.

Once we understand why we create religion, we can begin creating the social structures that will replace religion.
I was following along, agreeing with everything, until I got to that. The proffered reasons "why we create religion" (to address fear of death, to promote moral "goodness") seem percepetive and accurate but somehow incomplete. Other reasons are addressed throughout the many pages of the site, such as: to alieviate lonliness. The theist who claims God answered prayer gains attention from his or her peers, belongs to something beyond his or her self ... and the professional "witness for Christ" can use testimonial to make money. But I haven't a clue from that how we might "begin" to create "the social structures that will replace religion." I mean, to the extent we haven't already (law, education, science, medicine). The political dimension seems missing from this website. I suspect that's a deliberate rhetorical choice, but for the life of me I can't figure out why one would leave that out. The arguments set forth at Why Won't God Heal Amputees? seem to be addressed to a particular kind of person: the "theist" sort of conservative Christian who believes that a personal God answers specific prayers for medical treatment. I don't think such people are going to be persuaded by this approach. Superstituous theists are totally impervious to the modern scientific method, that is, the method outlined in Descartes' Discourse on Method: clear and distinct formulation of problems, reducing complex matters to simple cases using mathematics or logic, and proceeding from one empirically verifiable fact to another. Theists argue from "authority", that is: from the Bible, from contemporary authority figures and from the testimonials of other people like themselves. The site includes more than a few Bible quotes, but assumes a hostile method of exegesis every time. I have to wonder who this site is really aimed at. If you have any doubt about how a delusional, "God Answers Prayer" sort of Christian would react to this, take a look at this: Why Does God Hate Amputees? Or, Why Does God Love Marshall Brain?. This response demonstrates the "argument from authority" quite splendidly. Mr. Deem asserts that the arguments in "Why Won't God Heal Amputees" are "quite amateurish." Judging by web design, I think "Amputees" makes Deem's "Evidence for God" look an old Geocities site (which is apparently precisely what it is). I suspect what Mr. Deem means by "amateurish", however, is not web design. I suspect what Mr. Deem means that the folks who maintain "Amputees" are amateurs in the business of persuading delusional people. In the business of "apologetics", that is, persuading the kind of idiots who believe God answers prayers to give up their money and votes, I suspect Mr. Deem knows what he is talking about. He knows his audience. Yet these are the people "Amputees" purports to address. Page after page it tries to relieve the deluded of their delusions. So it seems a fair critique: how do such people think, and what sort of argument do they find persuasive? An authoritarian will want to know who is presenting an argument before scrutinizing the merits, the structure and content... assuming they can deal with the merits. So the first argument has to be the ad hominem. Rich Deem demonstrates for us: he starts by asserting that the author of "Why Won't God Heal Amputees" is Michael Brain, founder of "How Stuff Works". Mr. Deem says he "would have more respect" for Mr. Brain if he had not chosen to present the website anonymously. I don't know whether Mr. Deem has the intellectual agility to craft abstract arguments which could, anonymously and without indulging in digressions over personality or authority, go head-to-head with "Why Won't God Heal Amputees" . I suspect not, but that's beside the point. When folks like Mr. Deem claim to have "more respect" if some identifiable person claims authority, that's just a rhetorical flourish, or pure bullshit. They recognize only the authority of the voice of God which speaks in their head and tells them how to interpret the Bible. There's really no point in playing along. As for Rich Deem he runs a ministry in Pasadena (GodandScience.org) devoted to "Evidence for God". Mr. Deem seems to think that people who "believe in Science" will respond favorably to what a famous scientist, like Albert Einstein, has said about God. Anyone with a genuine interest in what Einstein had to say about about God is bound to be disappointed, but we're not talking about genuine intellectual interest here, we're talking about hijacking the authority which science has earned and employing it to further a political agenda. Mr. Deem transparently advances a right-wing political agenda. It only takes one or two clicks to get to the agenda (the usual: abortion, evolution, hating other kinds of Christians). So we know right away what agenda Mr. Deem is promoting, we know whose "side" he's on. That's important for authoritarians. Whose side is "Amputees" on? There are links on every page (after the Home page) to favorable reviews by famous contemporary atheists Sam Harris and Richard Dawkins, but that sort of begs the question. Yes, we know this is an "atheist" web site. Duh. But what political agenda does "Amputees" promote? If I switch sides, whose side am I on? "Amputees" discloses (eventually) an agenda promoting reason and justice and practicality (e.g. let's use medicine to cure ailments, not superstition) but that's not a "side". Anyone can "believe" in reason, in universal moral values. That's not what delusional Christians need to hear. What they need is a reason to hate some other group of people, in order to feel more powerful and less afraid. An authoritarian would rather invent some pernicious political agenda and impute it to "Amputees" rather than be satisfied with vague appeals to rationality, pragmatism and civilization. As for intellectual integrity, fundamentalist Christians have none, of course. "Amputees" repeatedly (and I think rather effectively) trashes religious mythology and method. Does Mr. Deems address any of thise? Are you kidding? When he's done calling out Michael Brain, Mr. Deem goes directly to the Gospel of Luke for "proof" that God (i.e. Jesus) heals amputees, citing the incident where Jesus restored the ear of a slave which has been struck off by one of Jesus' disciples. Mr. Deem does not need to address the systematic deconstruction of Christian literature and method, all he needs to do is say, "here's your proof: the Bible says so." Mr. Deem and his audience just don't care that their argument is circular and that their beliefs are a house of cards, or that they look completely crazy and stupid to others (though we are normally too polite to let them know that). Having made the obligatory Bible reference, Mr. Deem then launches into a sermon explicating the hate-theology of human depravity, in which no one is "worthy" of having their limbs regrown, so God says "no" to any such prayers. Yet God supposedly "loves" everyone (including the purported author of "Amputees", Michael Brain) in some way difficult to fathom and never proven. (I'm guessing God will show his "love" for Michael Brain by waiting until he dies and then condemning Mr. Brain to eternal torment. But why wait? Doesn't God already know ... oh, I'm sorry, I was approaching this rationally again). This is precisely the crappy rationalization which "Amputees" demolishes, at length, repeatedly, and without much humor (unless you've never given any of this a thought ever, in which case some of it might strike you as funny). Which brings me back to the question raised by "Why Won't God Heal Amputees?" That is, what function does religion serve? In particular, what function does this religion serve (the one which asserts that Jesus cures cancer)? For people who share Mr. Deem's political views against the rule of law, the integrity of science, against political freedom and religious tolerance, their hate-filled God delusion provides a sense of solidarity with others and empowerment in the face of authority. For example, on abortion: Mr. Deem's readers probably cannot understand the substantive due process analysis employed by the United States Supreme Court, the notion of the rule of law, or even articulate what criminal punishments would be appropriate if abortion were once again made a crime ... and they don't care. It just angers them to know that they have no authority to make these decisions. Some judge's assertion of authority over them diminishes them, makes them feel small and stupid. (It does not help that they are, in fact, a small group with stupid ideas.) It's the same with evolution: how dare these "scientists" assert authority in such an important field as ... science? It's the same with religious tolerance and political freedom. Never mind that we tried it their way for thousands of years and the results were terrible. It's all about authority, and a belligerent attitude towards all who claim it. Belligerance "empowers" delusional theists personally and politically. Personally (psychologically) it makes them feel better about themselves, and politically enables them to organize and act locally against their enemies. So I've beat this dead horse for several long paragraphs now: "Why Won't God Heal Amputees?" doesn't have a snowball's chance in hell of persuading Christians that they are delusional, just as Rich Deem's laughable "evidence" isn't going to persuade anyone any atheist that Deem's religion is not a psychotic delusion. In Deem's case we know what the real agenda is: right wing politics and personal enrichment (he's a professional, you see). In the case of "Amputees" I have to wonder who they think they are writing for and what they hope to accomplish. While it's demonstrably true that most people (if you you ask them the right questions) will reveal that they are neither strong believers nor strong atheists, I don't think this creates a massive "middle ground" ripe for persuasion one way or the other. People pretend to care about religion if that seems socially desirable, but really don't give a crap. We don't need to "understand" religion or cure religious zealots of their delusions in order to pursue rational social and political policies. We just create a wall of separation between Church and State and let the zealots live in their "Church" ghetto. Religious zealots don't really need action, they need reassurance. They'll take symbol over substance, because for them it's all about feeling not fact. An authoritarian U.S. President with the support of Congress could effectively destroy all organized religion above the congregation level (with regulaiton or taxation, say) but if he declared America a "Christian Nation" at the same time, the fundamentalists wouldn't care. In fact, to the extent that such actions would burden the politcal and charitable activities of Catholics, Jews, Muslims and mainline Protestant denominations, the fundies in their little non-denominational "mega-churches" would be deleriously happy with that.

Shigeru Miyamoto v. William Shakespeare ... How many of you know who is told "... our Princess is in another castle", and what the Princess' name is? How many of you know who argued "the quality of mercy is not strained" in a trial in a certain Shakespeare play, and who won and who lost in that trial? Inspired by (1) a rather irksome review of what may be a rather good book on video games, "Extra Lives" by Tom Bissell. Giving Roger Ebert a voice in this discussion is ludicrous. Hew clearly needs to be relegated to teevee expressing shallow opinions on even shallower movies. (2) questions from my ten year old about Augustus Caesar (because if you get the top score in Civ4, you are compared to him). I told him Augustus was not born either Augustus (a title conferred on him by the Senate) nor Caesar (he was adopted by Julius as his successor) which led to me handing him a few paperback copies of various versions of Plutarch's "Lives" and commenting that in the olden days, smart boys read these in Latin, but today we are content with translations.

I think all this focus on racial profiling misses the point entirely. Under the current interpretation of the Fourth Amendment, you can be stopped any time you are in a motor vehicle: talking on your cell, broken tailight, cracked windshield, dirt obscuring your registration sticker, tinting on your windows, any kind of erratic driving. That's "probable cause" stuff and doesn't even get to the "reasonable suspicion" level. "Reasonable suspicion" is mostly about expanding the scope of a stop the officers were already justified in making. I have this notion I'm going to exploit my DotMac account to make a professional blog page. If I get rolling with this --and the point of today's post is that I most likely won't-- maybe I'll throw some money at this, but I doubt it. There are many lawyer web pages out there which reflect someone's decision to spend a lot of money on marketing and then neglect to add any content. "Neglect" is probably too strong a word. There are lots of ethical and professional issues with respect to lawyers writing about what they do for public consumption. I would love to repeat everything I hear, read or see in the course of a day. Some of it is downright hilarious and would be fun to write about. There's plenty of material there both humorous and politically significant, morally significant, even ... but there are a range of rules, written and unwritten, ranging from the very serious lawyer-client confidentiality to simply a matter of good taste, which prevent me from writing about my own work. None of that would prevent me from writing about other lawyer's cases, though. I thought I had the perfect example: the City of Albuquerque was recently denied certiorari by the United States Supreme Court in a zoning case. I used to do zoning law and I am even quite familiar with this particular case. It's been pending for 15 years and there have been several State appellate decisions which I have duly read and applied in my work. This case isn't my case, however, so I have no professional scruples expressing any and all opinions I might have. However, when I read what I wrote, I found it boring, even to me. The upshot of "denial of cert" is that now the City will have to pay a judgment for $11 million dollars (at last count, likely 1 or 2 million more when interest and attorney's fees are added). The very next day the City announced that it was looking at job cuts and furloughs and non-specified "other ways" to address a $53 million budget shortfall. The new mayor is even making noises about breaching the City's contracts with its unions, under the not-very-legal notion that they were negotiated by the previous mayor and shouldn't burden this one. In short, the City's legal department and mayor(s) fucked up big time, and now they are going to make other people, their loyal employees, pay the consequences. All this to support an argument that when the City makes new zoning sector plans, this constitutes "legislation" and they can do whatever the fuck they want, whenever they want, to whoever they want. That's complete and utter bullshit. The obvious potential for corruption is made even more obvious by the facts of this case. There's a big area of empty land right in the middle of "Uptown" (Albuquerque's second "downtown" area with --at the time, 1995-- two major shopping malls, a half dozen office towers, located right off the main East-West freeway... in short, the center of the City now that's based on cars, rather than the railroads which were the hub of the old Downtown area). This particular parcel, however, had never been developed because it was owned by the city's premiere parochial high school (which ended up building a new high school in a completely different part of town). The proposed shopping mall was an obvious use for this parcel, obvious to the point where, in the intervening 15 years, an "upscale" shopping mall (Apple store, Pottery Barn, you name it) is just what went up on an enjoining parcel. So what was the problem? Traffic? There was going to be traffic no matter what. In the intervening 15 years, the State/City/Feds have expended millions to upgrade the freeway exit at exactly this spot. All factors point to... someone wanted this project to fail and that someone had clout with the City council. A case of political corruption pure and simple. But even "corruption" doesn't explain why the City decided to litigate this forever on the ridiculous ground that the City can do whatever the fuck it wants in zoning cases. I use the unsafe-for-Court term "whatever the fuck they want" because the accepted lawyerly term is "police power". That's confusing. It has nothing to do with the police department or law enforcement as we all understand it. I means the power of a city, as a local level government (unlike State or federal government which are limited by constitutions` and rules and shit) to make any laws it wants to address any problems it has, with little or no interference from courts at any level. You want to outlaw loud breathing within the city limits? Ducks on leashes? Fine: go for it. Anything you want, you got it. If you don't believe me look up one of those "silly laws" websites. There are, of course, limits on local "police power": State statute for one. New Mexico statutes on "zoning", however, are pretty vague and leave a lot of room for interpretation, and necessarily so because zoning issues are local issues. There's more, though. Looming over this whole cozy arrangement, this potential sphere for the unchecked, unfettered abuse of government power in the service of private money and power, way back in the mists of time and buried in student text books which everyone forgets the minute they pass the bar exam, is a little thing called the 14th Amendment, and its curious phrase: "due process". And as I noted above, our State statutes (and most state statutes) leave zoning pretty much up to the discretion of local government. looking only at the laws on the books, it's hard not to conclude that the City can, indeed, do whatever the fuck it wants, any time, to anyone. "Due process" has been silently invoked (sub silentio I think the Latin phrase is) by mentioning "fairness" in procedure, but the appeals courts more often than not invoke "police power" as the default rule: zoning laws are presumed correct unless it can be shown otherwise. How do you show otherwise? Well you can read 30 or so pages of legalese which appears to be state sort of rule or rationale, but the bottom line is always: Ha-ha, you can't. So the City's lawyers thought they could win on essentially technical grounds "this zoning change was passed by the City Council and therefore is a 'law' and can be crammed down people's throats and fairness and facts be damned" since, well, a lot of (poorly reasoned and badly written) New Mexico cases seem to imply just that. What those cases should have said was: this isn't unfair enough to invoke the Constitution to overrule the zoning change, with the appropriate reference to the technical standards for what is fair (and what isn't) in due process law, like our State courts did back in the 1970s (when men were men and law was law, dammit). And by "they" I mean a small circle of real estate lawyers and developers and development professionals and their pals on the appellate courts. I don't want to get fucking sued, and anyway, times have changed and power relations shifted and oh look at that: another of the City's biggest real estate brokers is about to go "poof" in an Enron-like maelstrom of securities fraud! For you, my limited circle of friends, I will say that here it's pretty clear "the government" (City) indulged in frivolous litigation and delay which a private sector entity could never get away with. You see, if this were a dispute between two commercial entities, their insurance carriers would have resolved it a long, long time ago for a lot less than $11 million dollars, at least half that, probably much less. In fact, New Mexico insurance statutes would have demanded that: they define "bad faith" as failing to promptly settle a case "when liability is reasonably clear". For those of you who don't know, "bad faith" is very bad for insurers. Among other things, insurers can be held liable for more than the limits of their policy, more than their contract amount and reserves set aside to pay the claim. That can mean bankruptcy, loss of investment rating... it can be the corporate "death penalty" with a sufficient large judgment and a relatively small or undercapitalized insurer. And with big insurers it means "heads will roll" in middle management. So, insurers stop litigating and start negotiating "when liability is reasonably clear"... or else. And in this case, liability has been "reasonably clear" from the outset. Can you change the zoning rules to make them more restrictive (we lawyers call that "downzoning") and apply them to a particular project after the paperwork has been filed for zoning approval? Of course not. Can you get around that by denying a hearing to a developer where the developer can show: yes, we filed before this change so it doesn't apply to us? Of course not. Yet, the City managed to convince the New Mexico Court of Appeals, and after that ruling was overruled by the State's highest court, hired some fancy DC law firm and paid them another 50 grand (after spending millions on their own lawyers) to make an utterly pointless and meritless appeal to the SCOTUS. It was all a massive waste of time and taxpayer money. All in the service of establishing "precedent" saying, no, you can't do whatever the fuck you want in zoning cases. This is why I don't do zoning anymore and restrict my practice to suing the government for more traditional "civil rights" violations.

We all know that nuclear power production results in toxic waste, but did you know that power from coal combustion also produces toxic waste? (I did). And do you have any idea how much toxic waste it produces? (I didn't, but now I do). The most irritating fact about coal ash is that, unlike nuclear waste, there are ways to effectively neutralize its hazards. We just aren't using them. If we did, alternatives would start looking that much more attractive, in terms of costs. On the other hand, if biofuels were ramped up to current levels of electrical production as coal, wouldn't they create similar toxic byproduct problems? How about photovoltaics? What do we do with all the old panels (full of exotic and potentially toxic materials) as the technology improves and we replace them with new ones? Recycle? Nukes look better and better the more I know. I'm especially intrigued by alternatives to uranium as fuel, but I know that's just theooretical at this point. No matter what we do, the true costs of our energy-intensive lifestyle have been hidden, subsidized, shifted on to others. And moving from oil to electric transportation will only make this worse. Go on, tell me I'm wrong.

Marxist terms and ideas need a serious update.  There's probably people out there doing this but I haven't even sharpened my thinking to know where to look, or recognize what I find.  Floundering around here...

<lj-cut text="Read More...">

Class

It seems pretty clear that the classic "proletarian/bourgeoisie" terminology is as obsolete as a buggy whip.

When the old feudal aristocratic orders were being liquidated by the rising "middle class" industrial capitalists, it made sense to talk about the "bourgeoisie", the class that was incubated in cities, towns and villages until it finally managed to mass enough wealth and power to completely displace the "aristocracy", the old, decentralized ruling class whose wealth was founded on the ownership of agricultural land.

Now anything and everything can be a "means of production".  Land? Yes.  Capital (in the sense of buildings and stuff)?  Sure.  But also legal rights and licenses, protected forms of expression, technical data such as gene sequences, a blob of cancer cells long ago extracted from a patient and replicated millions of times... basically anything that isn't used up after sale (a commodity) but rather persists and keeps on producing a profit.  We lawyers call that stuff "property", which is as good a word as any.

In my case, if someone were to ask me what my most valuable item of "property" was, I'd assume they meant "asset" and say my house.  Really, though, my most valuable property is my law license.  It's not transferable all at once (I can't grant you the right to play lawyer) and therefore has no price-based value.   I sell it off in 6 minute slices which add up to "billable hours".  While I, like most professionals, like to think that people hire me because I'm "smart" and "experienced" and can solve problems (and of course I market myself that way) what people are paying for is not these virtues of character but rather the license.  I can also counsel people with emotional problems (and my job as a lawyer has given me plenty of experience with that) but I'm not a licensed psychiatrist or counselor so I can't sell that.  While I make fun of lawyers who attach an "Esq." to their names, the law license is really very much like an old title of nobility when that meant something (when it was attached to a bundle of rights with respect to a particular collection of real estate).

That's just one form of "property", though.  Professionals aren't at all the new "bourgeoisie".  We are not a distinct "ruling" class.  We are owned lock-stock-and-barrel by the self-proclaimed "Masters of the Universe", the "Wall Street" financial elite who "own" 90% of everything "ownable".  Who are these people?  What do we call them?  Coming up with name seems to be hard, as if deliberately ... obscured.  Ideas of "ownership" are likewise obscured.  Corporations are now often owned mostly by institutions which hold aggregated funds: State employee retirement funds, for example.  "Ownership" in the technical sense is diluted, but control seems to be where it's always been.  

To call them "capitalists" conjures up activities which they long ago stopped doing, like inventing products and then buying the equipment to manufacture them.  They like to call investment contracts of various kinds "products" but that seems to me to bend and stretch the notion well past breaking point.  It seems to be part of a disinformation, propaganda and semantic dilution campaign, intended to subvert real class struggle in the classic Marxist sense.  "See? We're just like you!  We work and make 'products'!"  Yeah, right. 

You can say "rich" and "poor" but that's bland and essentially meaningless, especially for a Marxist who wants his terms to have some historical content and relevance.

Colonialism / Imperlialism

Circa 1848, the colonial operation was pretty simple: fund a military operation, take over some territory, enslave the local population and/or start importing workers, and build a resource extraction machine.  In those days it seemed the model of profit was to locate your manufacturing base in the home country and send out manufactured at a ridiculously high, tariff inflated price.  Unfortunately, this model encouraged colonies to declare independence. That model in its original form, with slave labor and ham-fisted tax and tariff policies, is dead.  

All the various European national colonial operations have been consolidated, moved to New York City and then reconfigured into administrative regions (much as Rome moved to Constantinople and then split into East and West).  And today the Empire cultivates local elites who import everything, even their children's educations, from the Empire, but still maintain an illusion of independence and local control (like, say, Mexico).  

Natural resource extraction is no longer the only profit-making colonial model: the raw material can be low wage labor or a place to dump toxic waste. The Empire is global now and you can't seize control of any part of it with armed revolution or peaceful political process.  Those things just give you control of a "nation", and nations are irrelevant now (and that goes double for political parties and the legislative bodies they are designed to control).  The old-style Communists could see this coming and at least talked about an "international labor movement", but in practice they just made more "nations", and those nations were eventually forced to abandon Communism, leaving the workers of the world with nothing in the way of an "international labor movement" except the quaint vestiges of trade unions.

Probably the reason why militant fundmentalist Islam has to be demonized as "terrorism" is that, at least to the extent it is trans-national, it's the closest thing to a threat to the Empire that exists.

Health Care Summit; Senator Tom Coburn, M.D. (R-OK), a wholly-owned subsidiary of the health care industry, managed to make me want to throw all the doctors under the bus (even though a lot of my friends are doctors) by using the term "extortion" to describe medical malpractice suits. Senator Coburn is a filthy rich gas-bag who uses overblown rhetoric to describe efforts to hold him accountable for his errors. His contribution to a sensible policy debate on this matter is to drop his drawers and shit on it. Like most plaintiff's lawyers (I suppose) I get lots and lots of calls and referrals ro do medical malpractice lawsuits, even though that's not my speciality. I do the job of screening them: get the medical records, review them and forward them to a guy I know from law school, a dual M.D./J.D. who knows his stuff. Most of the time we tell the family "sorry, that wasn't a clear case of malpractice" or "he would have died anyway". This is not a fun thing to have to tell people. One exception was a woman whose son died of a ruptured appendix. This case goes right to the heart of the "unnecessary" tests and "defensive medicine" issue. Most people who go to the emergency room or urgent care with abdominal pains and high fever do NOT have appendicitis. So doing the blood test recommended by emergency physicians is a total waste, some really high percentage of the time (maybe 99%). For that remaining 1%, however, it's a life-and-death issue. Weighing the low benefit against the very high cost, emergency physicians go with the test. But this kid wasn't at the emergency room. He saw a nurse at an urgent care facility, and she said "you just have a tummy ache and the flu" (or words to that effect) and did not order the test. Appendix ruptured, kid died. So we sued the HMO and won. Extortion? No doctors were threatened with a black mark on their record here, and frankly, the HMO and any doctor with malpractice insurance can afford to put on a defense like I've never seen in any other area of the law. We're talking scorched earth, Nazis-retreating-from-Russia style defense. There was no "extortion" involved here, nor (I'd bet) in the cases brought against Senator Coburn for his medical errors. What was involved was holding for-profit health corporations to account for a financial decision not to engage in "defensive medicine" and instead let people die. Nobody told the parent of this now dead child that she would have to give up her son so that everyone else can save a few bucks. This HMO doesn't advertise the fact that they keep premiums low by letting 1 out of 100 of you die. I don't think the objective of a "medical malpractice" system should be aimed at blaming doctors or even reducing malpractice. The legal system is a terrible way to achieve that kind of accountability. It's not even very good at compensating people who are the victims of medical errors: it's kind of like a lottery, in which many people participate but only a few receive (perhaps inflated) awards. To make it work, what we need is a system like the workers compensation system wherein payouts are standardized and held low, and in exchange, they are made promptly and without allowing doctors and health care corporations to spend millions on defense. In my state, worker's compensation lawyer's fees on both sides are capped at $16k per case: I'd like the see a malpractice defense lawyer do a case on that kind of budget. That would be extortion in many cases, but it's what Seantor Coburn and his ilk deserve. In the meantime, you better believe I won't be taking my kids to any "urgent care" or participating in any HMO that doesn't allow me to take them to the government-run University Hospital.

On the perennial theme of the degradation of language by technology: you know the sort of thing I'm referring to.  Some boomer or even more aged person, observes his/her child/grandchild doing some texting and immediately leaps to the conclusion that the compressed and colloquial features of electronic communication will be the death of longer, more thoughtful narratives possible with more tradition printed-on-paper written expression.  

If I meet these people in person, I always want ask (and if I am in a particularly nasty mood, I do ask) if they have read Plato's Phaedrus.  In that dialogue Socrates encounters one of his young friends using the latest techno-gadget of the day: he has a scroll with a speech on it, written by some other guy, which he is trying to memorize by repeating it out loud.  There follows a long dialogue about the difference between written wisdom and more free-floating oral communication (along with the issue of thinking for yourself rather than assimilating another's dead, static thoughts).  True: the introduction of writing for the Greeks killed the tradition of reciting epic poetry from memory.  To think that the Illiad and the Odyssey were once recited out loud... they were probably only recited in part, or episodes, and only gathered together in the form we know today once writing allowed that, but still, pretty amazing.  On the other hand, the irony of the Phaedrus is that we only know about Socrates bemoaning the implications of technology for philosophy because Plato used that technology (brilliantly) to convey his reservations to us. 2400 years ago.  Suck on that, luddites.

Frankly, every person who complains about "texting" needs to get out more often.  Ordinary oral communication is just as abbreviated and thoughtless as texting.  It's not a replacement for letter-writing, it's a replacement for chit-chat.  Get a life.

The United States Constitution is very difficult for pundits to understand. On the one hand it is government by the people (majority rule) but on the other hand it is government for the people (limits on government to preserve liberty). The latter, the counter-majoritarian impulse, confuses Washington Post columnist George F. Will, in a recent screed questioning whether it is constitutional to require people to get health insurance. For years Mr. Will and his fellow "conservatives" have attacked "judicial activism". Now, however, Mr. Will discovers a "more truly conservative" conservatism with favors judicial activism (when it involves striking down a law requiring people to buy health insurance):
More truly conservative conservatives take their bearings from the proposition that government's primary purpose is not to organize the fulfillment of majority preferences but to protect preexisting rights of the individual -- basically, liberty. These conservatives favor judicial activism understood as unflinching performance of the courts' role in that protection.
(emphasis in the original) Mr. Will is no more qualified to opine about constitutional law than he is to opine about global warming. Mr. Will begins with a rookie mistake: improper use of the "slippery slope". (He posits an imaginary law requiring everyone to do calisthenics.) Learning "to think like a lawyer" includes learning how to make the "slippery slope" argument properly. It should not be confused with the reductio ad absurdum, which is employed to expose absurd, unintended consequences of overly broad laws. "Slippery slope" is always a weak argument because it is always immaterial. It is impertinent by definition: Congress did not, in fact, require everyone to do jumping jacks. So why did Mr. Will bring this up? How is this relevant? On the other hand, "slippery slope" can be useful. It can reveal the underlying basis for some apparently arbitrary distinction (or conversely the lack of any rational basis) but you have to use it properly. Consider the difference between the following questions: "If we allow homosexuals to marry, what is to stop ... " GOOD: "... three or more people from marrying?" BAD: "... someone from marrying his box turtle?" Polygamy is relevent because there are people who desire it, it has a history and there is evidence to show it is a bad thing. There is no such history or evidence with respect to turtles. Polygamy violates social norms because of the history of abuse and neglect of women and children in these relationships. Abuse and neglect occur in traditional marriages as well, so, it's not the number of people in the marriage which is the problem, per se, but rather, it's an arbitrary distinction grounded in some evidence, which ultimately can be stated as "common sense": a man is more likely to be able to support and care for one family than two or more. I have no reason to think homosexuals are any more likely to abuse and neglect their partners and children, but "conservatives" think of homosexuality as inherently abusive, so this is what they need to prove. (Right now, in United States District Court, in the "Prop. 8" trial in San Francisco. Bring it on, Alliance Defense Fund, the whole world is watching.) Clearly, good use of the "slippery slope" technique has to be grounded in facts to reveal something or persuade anyone. To do "slippery slope" right, you want to choose a factual scenario which is close to the one you really care about, not a wildly absurd extreme which no one cares about. Applying this to health insurance, one might well ask, "if the government can require us to purchase health insurance, what's to stop them from requiring other kinds of insurance?" You mean, like car insurance? Or workers compensation insurance? Oh wait. Courts long ago concluded that mandating workers compensation insurance was not only fair, but a more efficient alternative to directly taxing businesses to pay for the public support of workers they have disabled. It is more efficient because the price of insurance is adjusted based on risk and loss history, so the more dangerous business pay more. In practice, this is done by having insurance companies present evidence for their different rates, and having a government agency accept or reject the rates, so there's neither a "free market" nor a government bureaucracy setting rates, but rather a "collaboration" accomplished in our traditional, adversarial mode, with a bunch of lawyers and heated debate on both sides, with plenty of "liberty" and due process involved. So Mr. Will's argument boils down to nothing more than asserting an interest in tax evasion, which may be a perennially popular "conservative" interest, but not a very effective constitutional legal objection.

Conservations with my 10-year old son have a marvellous way of concentrating my thinking. I drive Ben to his school every morning and we listen to the Stephanie Miller Show, which has the right blend of silliness and seriousness to appeal to both of us. This morning, Ben asked me why people are so pissed off about more airport security, in particular, the body-scanning machines in which DHS Director Michael Chertikoff has a financial interest. I pointed out to Ben that the millions of searches of millions of people since 9/11 had failed to catch a single terrorist, and we didn't catch this underwear bomber on Christmas Day. (I glossed over the deterrent effect: there's no doubt in my mind that metal detectors and such have made the job of a would-be hijacker/bomber difficult, and in particular, this guy failed because you can't bring an ordinary commercial explosives detonators on board, making the job of setting off a bomb much, much more difficult). Trying to explain the difference between police work as it is normally carried out, and airports, I told Ben that although we have a problem with drunk driving in New Mexico, police don't set up roadblocks every morning on I-25 and make everyone take sobriety tests every day. Instead, the police stop people who are driving suspiciously, and people with a DWI record have to use a sobriety interlock device on their vehicle. In other words, there has to be a some reasonable basis for intrusion in our privacy or inconvenience in our travel. There followed a brief, "this is your Dad the Lawyer speaking", run-down on what the Fourth Amendment requires for searches: at least reasonable suspicion for a warrantless search. TSA had no reasonable basis to search any of the millions of people who have flown since 9/11. Yeah sure there are "exigent circumstances", but it occured to me that the circumstances could be a lot less "exigent". With more time and resources on ordinary (preventive) police work, airport security could be reduced, for most people. For example, we had enough tips floating around in our government bureaucracy to justify a "reasonable suspicion" warrantless search of underwear bomber, even under my very strict notions of what the Fourth Amendment requires.
