So to recap, Plato posited three-part human soul.... somewhere he compares to a chariot with two horses and a driver. Needs and wants are the two horses, and the driver is basic prudence. Plato also described "virtues" or habits of conduct which corresponded to the various drivers: Temperance moderates the basic human needs: food, shelter, sex and probably also the need for love, friendship and social approval. Fortitude regulates our wants and ambitions, and the need to defend ourselves from the ambitions of others. Plato talks about fortitude as physical courage on the battlefield, but for us, in our desk-sitting world, however, "fortitude" is the endurance needed to delay gratification through school and apprenticeship, and bear the indignity of serving clients, customers and managers, facing problems with the appropriate balance between getting to work done and getting the work done right, until we achieve the victory of a vigorous and sustainable solution (and, hopefully, getting paid or promoted). Prudence keeps the needs and wants in check with "common sense", and anticipates dangers. Justice in the state or character habit in which all three of the basic virtues are adapted to reality, where the drives to satisfy basic needs are not allowed to "run wild", where prudence is not allowed to paralyze with doubt, paranoia or anxiety, and each of the virtues "mind their own business" and do what is appropriate for the sake of the whole person in light of the circumstances. The imaginary city-state Plato constructs in the Republic is obviously inadequate and could never exist. Likewise, Plato's assertion of "just" habits of living is open to all sorts of objections. At least one the interlocutors in the dialogue asserts an alternative ethic of excess, relying on strength and power over others to satisfy excessive needs and wants, as the way to the most "happiness". There is also due attention in the dialogue to the fact that, in any group of people, "appearing" just, rather than actually "being" just, often seems to be the best route to satisying the basic needs of the ego. Updating all the talk of battlefield courage to our symbol-manipulating battles, anyone with even casual experience with workplace drama knows that there exist people who demand recognition without deserving it, whose solutions to problems are neither vigorous nor sustainable but get "sold" to managers, customers or clients, using all the arts of persuasion and salesmanship and self-promotion which were well known to Plato's readers 2500 years ago. The technologies of rhetoric (advertising, marketing) may have become more "sophisticated" (pun intended: Plato's foes in the "marketing department" were called "Sophists") but the ethical problems remain the same. We can add "social virtues" to our list, such as honesty, care or respect, and we can even institute education to try and make those virtues habitual. Above all we need to inculcate a long term perspective in which youthful whining about how the "rules" are "stupid" is met with warnings about the injustice of force or fraud, but that's about all you can do. Youth doesn't have the experience to convert a warning into knowledge, and we are all "youth" to some extent because our lives are too short to learn everything the hard way. You can say "Do not attempt to stop chain with hands or genitals" all you want, but there will always be people who try. Socrates' interlocutors include some smart and ethical young men. They want to believe Socrates, to believe that justice is inherently better than injustice, and that the "just" person will be the happy person in the long run, but they despair over the prospect of the "just" being deprived of happiness by injustice armed with force or fraud. To give the "long run" argument a bit more length, Socrates posits an immortal soul and tells the Myth of Judgment, wherein unjust conduct is suitably punished. Traditionally, this is where philosophy ends and religion begins: with the lies of immortality and Judgment, or a "leap of faith" over despair. Here you can conclude that religion is all lies, or "a means of social control" or "the opiate of the masses" or "a dangerous delusional meme" ... whatever skeptical lens you chose to use, it's all good in my opinion, or good enough for most people and most of the time. Unfortunately for me, I am not "most people". I foolishly chose the trade of fighting injustice for a living. Force and fraud are my bread and butter, so to speak. The despair of Scorates' young men is something very concrete for me, not an abstract problem which arose once in a dorm room discussion but never again. I have good and practical reasons to dare to penetrate the exoteric manifestations of religion and look for the esoteric, secret mystical insights which continue to drive the whole social phenomenon of religion, hidden away behind the screen of lies, delusions and superstitions. To that end... I found this most mysterious but intriguing passage in Augustine, embedded in one of his tiresome polemics. Reading Augustine is often tedious because he's arguing with people you have never heard of, for reasons long lost to history. In this case, his opponents are the "Manicheans". It should suffice for us to note (1) the Manicheans were one of many groups who tried to blend Hellenic philosophy with Hebrew religion, most of whom, thanks to Augustine, have been cosgined to the dustbin of history as "heresies", (2) they employed a dualistic system in which there are two co-equal "Gods", one good, the other evil, (3) they identified Yahweh in the Old Testament with the evil god, and Jesus in the New Testament as the representative of the good god, and regarded the Jewish Law as the work of the Devil. Finally, it helps to know that Augustine started out as a Manichean but then converted to the "Catholic" variety of Christianity and became its most formidable spokesperson ever. The book I am looking at is called "The Morals of the Catholic Church", but "Catholic" here doesn't mean what we think it means, but rather means "not Manichean or Gnostic or Arian", because this is around 400 CE, long before the Great Schism between Latin and Greek Christianity (around 1000 CE) and a thousand years before the Catholic/Protestant divide (around 1500 CE). All Christian sects surviving today are branches of Augustine's "Catholic" church. Here's what Augustine had to day about Plato's scheme, "the cardinal virtues" of temperance, fortitude, prudence and justice.
As to virtue leading us to a happy life, I hold virtue to be nothing else than perfect love of God. For the fourfold division of virtue I regard as taken from four forms of love. For these four virtues (would that all felt their influence in their minds as they have their names in their mouths!), I should have no hesitation in defining them: that temperance is love giving itself entirely to that which is loved; fortitude is love readily bearing all things for the sake of the loved object; justice is love serving only the loved object, and therefore ruling rightly; prudence is love distinguishing with sagacity between what hinders it and what helps it. The object of this love is not anything, but only God, the chief good, the highest wisdom, the perfect harmony. So we may express the definition thus: that temperance is love keeping itself entire and incorrupt for God; fortitude is love bearing everything readily for the sake of God; justice is love serving God only, and therefore ruling well all else, as subject to man; prudence is love making a right distinction between what helps it towards God and what might hinder it.
So, Augustine asserts that love of God perfects all the Greek virtues. It overcomes despair and takes the place of the Myth of Judgment in Plato's scheme. Which is all fine and good, but what the heck is it? If you are like me, both "love" and "God" here are mysterious undefined terms. Clearly he can't be talking about "love" in any of the ways we ordinarily use the word. Love of chocolate, love of reading, the love we once had for ex-girlfriends or boyfriends... none of that applies. Marriage and parenthood come closer: the metaphor Jesus used for the relationship between people and God was nearly always the parent/child relationship (sometimes it was master/servant, but usually only in strange little parables that obviously require some interpretation to understand). Later, Christians seized upon the Jewish religious theme of the Messaiah as the "Son of God", and talked about the relationship between Jesus and the Church as a "marriage", but parenthood, specifically patriarchal parenthood between Father and Child, was the metaphor Christians always liked the most. This has never been helpful to me. I can say a lot about my father, both good and bad, but for your purposes I can sum up the bad as follows: "drunken frat boy who grew up and had a family, but never really grew up". The one thing most flawed about my father was the one thing most necessary for a "Father in Heaven": someone you can trust. Who knows? Maybe Jesus had issues with Joseph and imagined for himself a better father, a Perfect Father... but this was something I could never quite do. So let's toss that and focus on what Augustine calls God here: "the chief good, the highest wisdom, the perfect harmony". Here again I have problems. Defining God by superlatives becomes the preferred method in academic, philosophical theology. Anselm is perhaps the most obnoxious proponent of this method, when he defines God as "that which nothing greater can be conceived". He's taken all the content out of the description and left nothing but the structure: imagine the best thing you can: God is better than that. I have one word for this approach and that word is: sophomoric. I can't say my approach is not without its flaws, but it doesn't have the obvious logical flaw of the "superlatives" approach ("Can God create a weight he cannot lift?"). I want to know who God is and I want to know how love of God is not only possible, but can improve my character in all the ways that Augustine describes in the above-quoted passage. Only then could Jesus make sense for me, when he says the sum and substance of the Jewish law is: "Love God, and love your neighbor as yourself." This is where I begin talking about God as an imaginary friend who represents all knowledge. I can anticipate objections. One good one is the positivist objection that "ought cannot be derived from is". If you think of "knowledge" as a matter of language: statements, propositions, perhaps based on empirical knowledge, then this seems a very good objection indeed. I reply that this isn't logical derivation from a small set of experiments or experiences, however rigorously contrived, but a massive brute force experiment on an almost unimaginable scale: evolution and natural selection, capped with 100,000 years of cultural experience as a social animal. Genetics and culture don't always express themselves in language and logic: language is but one example of culture. Moreover, there comes a point where the mere "quantity" of data becomes a "quality" in itself, a quality which is lost by the logical method of taking complex problems and reducing them to simple components. When philosophers and theologians use the "superlatives" method of defining God (or proving that God "exists") this is the direction they are pointing in, this is the perspective they want us to have: really, really big. (But a whole lot of nothing is still nothing. You need to start with something substantial before you start magnifying it.) I think we have learned more from our failures than from our successes. In the course of Earth's history, sometimes Life's experiments have catastrophic effects. Progress in one area can result in disaster in others. An example which intrigues me is the Late Devonian mass extinction which ushers in the Carboniferous Age. One theory for the cause of this extinction event is plant evolution: plants developed vascular systems which allowed their stems to grow tall, spread branches, and send roots deep into the soil. This allowed the "greening" of the land masses, the spread of plants across the continents. This in turn may have caused a transition from "Greenhouse Earth" to "Icehouse Earth" as the plants removed carbon dioxide from the atmosphere, and stored in in the ground in the form of decaying plant matter, and also "anoxic" conditions in coastal areas (roots released massive amounts of plant nutrients, this causes marine plant blooms which reduces the amount of oxygen in the seas). Either lower sea levesl or anoxic conditions, or both, decimated marined life, particularly in tropic reefs. It took millions of years for reef-building marine life to reassert itself. Thus, "progress" in one area (for plants) may be an "evil" for other life forms, in the short run at least. The "knowledge" we are talking about here is an interdependent and highly conditional system. Perhaps more significant from a theological point of view, however: (1) knowledge must be enacted by some agent to produce any change or result in the world, and (2) the knowledge system I am describing is finite and progressive. My definition therefore requires me to abandon the notion of an all-powerful God who can perform sudden miracles which defy the laws of nature or necessity, or who can do anything without our agency. We are God's servants. "God helps them who help themselves". Can God create a weight He cannot lift? No. Does God have knowledge which as yet does not exist (possible future knowledge)? No. God is finite, but big enough to be practically infinite to you, the individual. This may come as a shock to people who for whom religious and spiritual life consists almost entirely of wishful thinking, praying to God for miracles, but the truth is, I not only willing but eager to eject such people from my system. Belief in an anthropomorphic warlord diety who has to be appeased by various sacrifices (or obedience to whimsical "laws") in order to perform miraculous favors for your tribe is childish, superstitious and idolatrous. In the story of life on Earth, your tribe's peculiar concerns of the moment are as nothing, and no sacrifice you can make is going to alter that. It comes down to this: love of God should be easy to understand (if not so easy to put into practice) if, as some say, "self-love" is ubiquitous and all-powerful, provided you have a sufficiently huge notion of "self". Clearly that's what Jesus assumed when he said: "love they neighbor as thyself." Loving God extends this to loving all life, present and past, for what it has attempted and continues to attempt. The story of life on earth has yet to be told completely, but it is enough to inspire faith, hope and love.

As I contemplate the complete repudiation of politically-correct toys in my household this year (the boys are running around with variety of Nerf armaments, ranging from swords to machine pistols to a fully automatic "Vulcan" machine gun which, aside from its garish colors and sponge ammo, looks like something a Hollywood action hero might heft, complete with ammo belt and large carrying handle) my thoughts turn to writing a rationalist's glossary of common religious terms. One of the biggest impediments to rational discussion of religion is the tendency of believers to speak in a self-referential and tautological "code" of religious terms. It's one thing to say that, ultimately, religion involves things which are articles of "faith". It's quite another to quite another to digsuise a lot of pseudo-religious opinion-mongering and unabashed speculation in a thick haze of vague words which mean one thing to the speaker and quite another to just about everyone else. To take my favorite extreme example, "God hates fags": maybe your "God" does Mr. Phelps, but I don't think anyone else's does. Even his political allies on the issue of "fags" are quick to correct him: "God" hates the "sin", not the "sinner". I'm a "believer" in the limited sense that I think the Christian message, the "Gospel", is by the far the most appropriate way of life and political attitude, with or without all the theological and cultural baggage that has attached itself to the Gospel. I subscribe to the Christian table of virtues ("faith", "hope" and "charity") above any personal ethic of self-aggrandizement (making virtues of strength, power, or wealth) or even virtues with some social utility, such as valor, honor, diligence or honesty. Clearly, though, if I am to discuss this with anyone outside the extremely limited circle of people who are not only Christian but my kind of Christian (basically, educated liberal Christians) I will need to define all these terms (Gospel, faith, hope, charity, prayer, love and of course, God) divergently instead of convergently. While it makes perfect, concise sense to me to say "faith is trust in God" referring back to God in the definition raises more questions than it answers, even for people with their own working definitions and cultural referents for "God", let alone people who have no idea what that word really means. So, to begin: "God" Lucky for us there has been a lot of real science directed toward religion in the past twenty years. Not just the spinning of hypotheses, either, but the beginnings of proper tests for those hypotheses, with ethnographical fieldwork, archeology, evolutionary psychology and a whole host of scientific disciplines. One hypothesis for an innate cognitive preference or faculty for religious belief is the "hyperactive" or "hypersensitive" agency detection device (HADD), a model which comes out of the field of "Cognitive science of religion" Events in our environment, such as a ripple in the tall grass, may be random events caused by natural forces such as the wind, or they may be evidence of an "agent", an animal hiding in the grass such as a lion. There would be a clear adaptive advantage to presume that the event was caused by an agent (predator, prey, another human) at least until heightened attention reveals no further evidence of such an agent. The fact that HADD is "unreliable" or frequently wrong (it's just the wind) is a small price to play for not being eaten by a lion or killed by an enemy or missing dinner. It is a "wasteful" and inefficient investment of imagination, but worth the cost in the long run. (Jumping ahead a bit: "waste" becomes a theme in religion, and especially Christianity. Waste and inefficiency seem to be the way religion works, compared with alternatives, and assuming you have an alternative. For example: "love your enemies" seems to be a rather inefficient approach, if you instead have the opportunity to completely annihilate them. More often than not, however, complete annilhilation is neither possible nor desirable, and you are stuck with on-going antagonism or cooperation.) This is interesting so far as it goes, and explains the beginnings of animism and beliefs in nature spirits and so forth, but religion does far more than attribute "agency" to an event. It gives the agent a name, and a geneogology and family history. It projects intentions, purposes and consciousness to the agent. For example, a person sees lightning and calls the agent "Thor" (or "Zeus" or pick your favorite) and tells stories about why Thor hurled the lightning bolt and what Thor wants. To explain the content of HADD-initiated agency stories, I would add ancestor worship or veneration, and ponder the significance of very ancient and universal burial practices. It is a very small step, semantically, from saying "I remember the advice Elder Gak gave me ten years ago, before he died..." to saying "the spirit of Elder Gak appeared to me and said....". The need for this sort of thing is obvious when we consider what people learn over the course of their lives and the experience lost when people die. There is an adaptive advantage to preserving, accumulating and transmitting life experiences: no need to "re-invent the wheel", so to speak. We can develop technologies (writing) and social institutions (universities) and try to do this in some rigorous manner, but even after large scale social organization makes things like that possible, it remains desirable to give experience a bit of vibrancy and power as an intellectual meme. One way to do this is to attribute an idea or saying to a peculiarly influential ancestor. The Illiad and the Odyssey were likely the result of an oral tradition spanning generations, but it was easier to attribute authorship to a well-known poet who was involved in the process (Homer). Likewise, the first five books of the Scriptures are attributed to "Moses", and even today people attribute all sorts of clever sayings to Abraham Lincoln, which upon rsearch turn out to have originated with other, more obscure personages. Over time, the distinction between attributing a mathematical theorem to a group ("the Pythagoreans") or one increasingly legendary and mythic personage ("Pythagoros") loses any real signifiance, and for everyone who is not a pedant, it may be sufficient to simply say "the Greeks". Conversely, there may be social and political advantages to taking the laws of a Babylonian king (Hammurabi) and attributing them to a Hebrew hero (Moses). Of course. the accumulation of "experience" can also become the accumulation of error. We can apply experience inappropriately, or hold onto "laws" long after they have become outmoded, and "authority" can give a weak opinion more value than it deserves. It is, though, in a way, a self-correcting mechanism. In the process of apotheosis, the elevation of an ancestor to demi-god to montheistic "God" or perhaps even a free-floating agentless body of "enlightenment", the fictitious agent must be come more complex, and incorporate more diverse experience and opinions. All the major world religions are frightfully complex. If you can say, "I know what God wants here" or "I know precisely how to follow the eightfold path to enlightenment in this situation" then I daresay you weren't really paying attention in your religious education. Only simpletons can ask "What Would Jesus Do?" and expect to get clear, positive directions. We see this all the time in contemporary politics in the United States, where the assertion of allegedly "Christian" values such as aversion to homosexuality can be readily, obviously and directly countered by the words of Jesus himself, who preached above all "love thy neighbor" and frequently counseled tolerance for the "sins" of others. Indeed, there's no claim by radical rightwing "Christians" that can't be refuted by reciting Jesus chapter and verse, and that's not because Jesus was invariably a "liberal" in the modern sense. (I don't think modern liberals could enthusiastically embrace Jesus' hard-core views against divorce, for example). Rather, it's because the reported sayings of Jesus already represented a diverse and rich religious tradition at the time they were first written down, and the passage of two thousand years has not made understanding their words any easier. It seems to me ridiculous to object that falsifying the experience by attributing it to a fictional agent (say, Thor) impedes proper scientific investigation of natural phenomenon (say, lightning). Science will inevitably progress when the foundations for invetigaiton are laid: in the case of lightning, when the notions of static electricity and positive and negative charge are introduced and developed. I would even go so far as to downplay the social danger of misattributing intention to the fictitious entity, at least over the long term. A religious authority might say: "Thor hurled that lightning bolt because he disapproves of your dishonorable behavior!" Persons who do that sort of thing are going to make such judgments and pronounce them one way or another, and it hardly addresses the moral suasion or political power of the religious leader to say, "no, lightning is the discharge of electrical potention when the clouds have one charge and the ground has another!" One does better to directly attack the influence of the leader, perhaps by recalling previous instances of self-interested predictions or evidence of bribe-taking, rather than confusing everyone with a distracting assault on religious fictions. The fact that "Christian" televangelists put words in Jesus' mouth to serve their own political or financial agenda is a lot less damning to me than specific evidence that Jim Bakker pocketed money intended for Bibles to Africa, and even the ones who have never been caught with their hands in the till (say, Pat Robertson) live pretty high on the hog. And if there is no such evidence of corruption, perhaps the leaders pronouncements are worthy of deference despite his or her unscientific manner of expression. In short, an unexamined pose of skepticism towards fictional agents seems to me just as lazy, ignorant and stupid as unexamined belief: neither takes on the work of investigating, analyzing and prioritzing claims. I begin with the hypothesis that God is an imaginary friend, representing all experience accumulated over the course of life on Earth, with narrowing factors such as the experience of humans, the experience of my particular culture, nation or community, and so forth. In this view "Science" is not opposed to "faith", Science is one of the many attributes of God.

Is Jesus "the Reason for the Season"? Nonsense. The reason for the season is the earth's axial tilt. At latitudes closer the the poles, this causes the pattern of seasonal weather variation and the shortening and lengthening of days on a yearly cycle. With the advent of agriculture this pattern was observed with some precision, and since Neolithic times it has been celebrated and mythologized. Wine and beer produced following the harvest had time to ferment and become drinkable, cattle were slaughtered to reduce the amount of feed necessary during the winter months, and especially at extreme northern latitudes, a festival atmosphere could help combat the depressive symptoms of seasonal affective disorder. The utility and popularity of these celebrations has allowed them to survive despite Christian efforts to suppress them or appropriate them. Early Christians did not celebrate the birth of Jesus. Origen even attacks birthday celebrations as the narcissitic preoccupation of earthly rulers, such as Pharaoh and the Roman puppet Herod. For the first Christians, the most important events in the life of Jesus were his death and resurrection, celebrated at Easter. Early (200-300 CE) Christian calendars varied, noting either the nativity or the conception at the spring equinox (thus implying a December birth) but nothing at the winter solstice. The death of Jesus is the center of Christian faith and is described in detail in all four Gospels and the Epistles, but his birth is mentioned in only two Gospels. Only Luke and Matthew make any effort to mythologize the birth of Jesus. Luke, writing for a Hellenic audience, has Joseph and Mary travel to Bethlehem from their home in Nazareth. Matthew, writing for Jews, simply has him born in Bethlehem and incorporates themes from the life of Moses (Pharoah killing the first-born) and Messianic prophecies (the appearance of magi from the East). Matthew clearly isn't relating "facts" but putting Jesus in a mythological context, and in any event, the compilers of the Scriptural canon didn't care enough about the issue to bother to reconcile the divergent accounts. Efforts to appropriate Roman winter solstice celebrations and give them a Christian religious significance commenced in the Byzantine (Eastern) Roman Empire in the late 4th Century, along with other efforts to establish to impose an official, imperial "Catholic" Christianity based in Rome. The celebration of Saturnalia was the Roman version of a Greek holiday celebrating Zeus' victory over his father (the old god Chronos, or Saturn for the Romans) which constituted a revolution among the gods to establish a new Olympic partriarchy. Saturnalia had "role-reversal" features where masters made a show of serving their slaves, along with a permissive attitude toward drunken revelry and sexual promiscuity. For centuries thereafter, Christians attacked the moral depravity and excess of Christmas merry-making as "paganism" (a political epithet roughly equivalent to charges of "Communism" today) but the "role reversal" feature of Saturnalia persisted in the Middle Ages with landlords presenting gifts to their tenants around Christmas time (reversing the usual feudal obligation of the tenant farmer to support the warrior landlord). Up through the Middle Ages the the emphasis was on a "season" or period of days (Advent or "the twelve days of Christmas") rather than a particular day. Marking December 25 as a particularly important day began after Charlemagne was crowned Emperor on Christmas Day in 800. Protestants were divided on the significance of Christmas. Luther loved Christmas and gave sentimental sermons about the Baby Jesus, backed by a renewed interest in the theological significance of the Incarnation of God as Man. Kill-joy iconoclast Calvinists, on the other hand, who had a tendency to vandalize religious art which they believed misrepresented the Scriptures, continued the tradition of debunking Christmas as a pagan celebration. The final Anglo-American synthesis of the religious holiday with the German "Yule" celebrations (evergreens, fires and candles, Santa Claus, gift-giving) didn't happen until the 19th Century. Christmas trees became popular with the importation of the German Hannover clan (the Georges and Victoria) to rule the United Kingdom. Still, for two thousand years, and especially after the Reformation, serious-minded Christian leaders were well aware of the pre-Christian origins of the popular seasonal celebrations and preached and agitated against them. Jesus was not "the reason for the season" but quite the contrary, the reason for saying, "bah, humbug". Then in 1843, Charles Dickens published A Christmas Carol, overwhelming radical Protestant opposition to the "pagan" or "popish" trappings of ancient winter solstice celebrations with a massive blast of schmaltz, sentimentality and nostalgia, and an ingenious appropriation of the ancient myth of annual role-reversal to preach a socialist message of compassion for the poor. It is about this time that many popular Christmas carols were published and started infiltrating church services, and merchants began to see the economic utility of promoting gift-giving. As Hegel noted in his introduction to the Phenomenology of Spirit, in a master-servant relationship it is the servant who gains knowledge and understanding of the material world by being compelled to work with it, whereas the master has a tendency to become alienated from reality. From master and slave, feudal lord and tenant, Victorian banker and clerk, right down to Mr. Potter (capitalist pig) and George Bailey (socialist vanguard) in Frank Capra's It's a Wonderful Life, Christmas has been the time in which we assert the necessity of compassion, community and yes, wasteful and conspicuous consumption, against oppression imposed without recognition of the suffering and sadness which can accompany winter in these northerly climes. It is in this context that we revive the fabrications of Luke and tell a story of a poor couple traveling to Bethlehem who can find no room at the inn, and thus are compelled to bring the Messiah, God himself, into the world in a stable, attended only by a some shepards and a trio of illuminated foreigners who have followed the signs in the heavens and acknowledge the baby as king and priest, and prophesize his death as suffering Savior of the world, with gold, frankincense and myrhh.

Health insurance is about to become a tightly regulated form of insurance, and this is a very good thing, with or without any kind of "public option". Allow me to illustrate by "length of policy". The length and number of exclusions and exceptions in an insurance contract reflects what the insurer thinks they can get away with. The more claims they can get away with not paying, the more exclusions and exceptions they stick in the policy. The shortest policies are issued in regulated types of insurance, and the shortest of all are in mandatory regulated insurance (workers compensation and motor vehicle insurance). Car insurance tends to be short: 12-20 pages depending on how they format it. Business liability insurance issued by an authorized, regulated insurer, by contrast, runs 50-100 pages (which actually makes sense because it covers a lot more situations). Business liability insurance issued by unauthorized, unregulated ("surplus lines") insurers on the other hand, tends to run to book length: 500 pages of exceptions and conditions and exclusions. That's the type of insurance you get if you operate a high-risk business (selling alcoholic beverages, for example) which typically no insurance company authorized to do business in your State will cover. A typical health insurance policy, on the other hand, is like an entire library. Health insurance contracts negotiated by business, institutions and unions can't be bound under a single cover, but typically fill an entire shelf of binders. You, the consumer, typically never see these, you get an "explanation" or "summary" (which by itself can be monstrous). All of that is going to be history soon. Now, of course, even motor vehicle insurers will try to cheat you. But they typically do it through claims adjusting (low-balling the amount of damages) and not by denying coverage. They can't pull tricks that are common in health insurance. They can't (legally) say: "you failed to disclose a pre-existing crack in your windshield therefore we aren't paying for your windshield". If they did that, and you sued, a judge would say "I don't care what your policy says: this is mandatory insurance and all property damage from a collision is covered." They can't require complicated and burdensome loss notice paperwork: you failed to present your card, and your doctor failed to fill out form X83/B, and you both failed to stand on your head and recite the Pledge of Allegience, therefore your dialysis isn't covered. Another advantage to this is that once health care providers are relieved of a lot of burdensome and non-uniform claims paperwork, it will be a lot easier to catch the ones who engage in fraud. Instead of "is this procedure on our list?" the question becomes "did you actually perform this procedure?" which is a much more important question for reducing costs. The same goes for tricks like areas of coverage and provider networks and so forth. The only allowable exception in auto insurance I am aware of is driving in Mexico: they are allowed to exclude that. They can't refuse to pay because you went to your favorite body shop instead of their approved shop. They can't exclude driving at night, or in the rain, or crossing State lines. They can't exclude drunk driving. I can't think of another area of contract law where you can engage in risky, illegal conduct and still enforce the contract... but you can with mandatory "no fault" insurance. (Incidently, my experience litigating motor vehicle coverage also makes doubt whether competition from a "public option" will really "keep insurers honest". The motor vehicle insurance industry is fiercely competitive, more so than any government-run insurance would ever be, and yet companies like Allstate still exist. Allstate is notorious among lawyers for having the most evil and dishonest claims practices in the industry). Granted, the State and federal regulations which will take the place of privately negotiated contracts will be long. But they will not be written to deliberately deny benefits. As mandatory insurance, they will be interpreted in a court of law to give you the coverage which you paid for and which "public policy" now demands. Not only will some claims-denial tricks like "rescission" for "misrepresentation" be specifically outlawed, but many tricks not covered or anticipated in the current legislation will fail in court. Why? Because when you make insurance mandatory, it ceases being a private contract covered exclusively by the written policy and presumably negotiated in good faith by two parties with equal bargaining power, but becomes a matter of "public policy". "Public policy" in plain English means a reason for judges to write you coverage even if it isn't spelled out in your contract, and even if the written contract says "No", a judge can say "Yes". I wonder if health insurance companies are ready for this. I'd bet that in company legal departments all over the country, lawyers are getting extremely frustrated trying to warn management that things are gonna change. What may happen is something similar to what happened in the mortgage-lending business: lots of people could foresee massive default and foreclosure problems looming, but companies like Countrywide just kept plugging away until they were destroyed, bankrupt, or purchased by another lender.

US border patrol roughed up a Canadian writer who was attempting to cross the border to drive home. No details as to why the border cops engaged in this behavior (excessive force, confiscation of property, and then abandonment) but there can be no legal justification for it. None. I'm particularly concerned about the abandonment. In my view, when the police arrest someone, take someone's liberty away (and his car, and communications devices and in this case even his clothing) I believe they become legally responsible for what happens to them. In this case, not much happened, but I know of at least one case where a mentally ill man wandered off into the desert and died of hypothermia. This is a difficult legal issue, though. Holding people accountable for their stupidity is never easy. The one thing I disagree with digby about: this sort of thing hasn't "escalated" recently. Police misconduct in the United States has always been a problem, for some people more than others. Indeed, I've been contemplating a few posts on why I've made police misconduct the focus of my law practice. First because it's a bad thing worth fighting, but also because it seems so deeeply ingrained in our society that I'm pretty sure I can spend the rest of my career doing these cases, and making a lot of money. A growth industry, as it were.
